stem: A 22-year-old trauma client has been in a deep coma with fixed and dilated pupils for 48 hours following a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). Based on the documentation in the provided tabs, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Initiation of brain death determination protocol.
Background: Motor vehicle accident with severe diffuse axonal injury.
Assessment: Client is GCS 3T. No spontaneous respirations.
Recommendation: Formal apnea test and organ procurement organization (OPO) notification.

tabs.title: Brain Death Protocol Log
tabs.content:
CriteriaCurrent FindingInterpretation
Pupillary Light ReflexAbsent (Fixed/Dilated)Brainstem failure
Corneal / Gag ReflexesAbsentBrainstem failure
Apnea TestPCO2 reached 62 mmHg; No respiratory effortPositive for Brain Death
Doll’s Eyes (Oculocephalic)No eye movementBrainstem failure

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 90/52 (Pressor dependent), HR 68, RR 0 (Ventilator dependent), T 95.2°F (Poikilothermia).

actionOptions.text: Notify the local Organ Procurement Organization (OPO) as required by policy
Maintain hemodynamic stability (fluids/vasopressors) to preserve organ function
Inform the family that the ventilator is supporting the client's breathing

parameterOptions.text: Absence of brainstem reflexes and spontaneous respirations
Verification of a normothermic core temperature (> 36°C) for valid testing

rationale.correct: The client meets the criteria for Clinical Brain Death (c2). The criteria for brain death include a known cause (TBI), absence of brainstem reflexes (p1), and a positive apnea test (PaCO2 > 60 mmHg with no respiratory effort). It is crucial to ensure the client is normothermic (p2) before testing, as hypothermia can mimic brain death. Once brain death is declared, the nurse must notify the OPO (a1) and maintain hemodynamic stability (a2) to ensure organ viability if donation proceeds.
clinicalPearls: Poikilothermia (inability to regulate body temperature) is common in brain death due to hypothalamic dysfunction.
The nurse should not initiate the conversation about organ donation; that is the responsibility of the OPO representative.
Fixed and dilated pupils in brain death are typically mid-position (4-6mm).

questionTrap.trap: Initiating the conversation about organ donation before the OPO arrives.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Only trained OPO staff should make the request for organ donation to avoid conflicts of interest and ensure appropriate communication.

mnemonic.title: Brain Death Assessment
mnemonic.expansion: Absent Gag reflex, Absent Oculocephalic reflex (Doll's eyes), No spontaneous Breathing (Apnea test), EEG flat/Brainstem dead.
